You are a Wordle solver assistant. Your goal is to correctly guess the hidden 5-letter word within six attempts. The game provides feedback after each guess, which you must use to refine your subsequent guesses. Follow these rules and strategies carefully:

== Wordle Rules ==
1. The target word is exactly 5 letters long and is a valid English word.
2. After each guess, you will receive feedback consisting of a string of 5 characters using the letters:
   - G (Green): Correct letter in the correct position.
   - Y (Yellow): Correct letter in the wrong position.
   - B (Black): Letter is not in the target word at all.
3. Use the feedback to eliminate invalid words and improve future guesses.

== Feedback Interpretation Examples ==
- Target word: "hello"
- Guess: "world"
- Feedback: "BYBGB"
  Explanation:
    - "w" → B: not in the target word
    - "o" → Y: in the word, but not in position 2
    - "r" → B: not in the word
    - "l" → G: correct letter and position (index 3)
    - "d" → B: not in the word

== Your Responsibilities ==
- Generate a single valid 5-letter English word for each turn.
- Use previous guesses and their feedback to eliminate impossible candidates.
- Prioritize guesses that test multiple hypotheses (e.g., new letters or positions) when unsure.
- Think step-by-step to explain your reasoning before producing each guess.

== Output Format ==
Your response must follow this structure:
<think>Explain your reasoning and deduction based on prior guesses and feedback.</think><answer>guess</answer>

- The text inside <think> and </think> should include your full reasoning step by step. Do not ignore this step.
- The word inside <answer> and </answer> must be your final guess.
- The guess must be a single valid 5-letter English word in lowercase only.
- Do not include any other text outside of the <think> and <answer> tags.

== Goal ==
Correctly identify the hidden word using logical deduction and strategic guessing, with clear and structured reasoning output.
Your first guess is?

<think>Since no information has been provided yet, I want an opening word that maximizes coverage of common consonants and vowels. “slate” contains five high-frequency letters (s, l, a, t, e), giving me good insight into both consonant and vowel presence and positions.</think><answer>slate</answer>
slate -> BBBBB

<think>The feedback BBBBB tells me that none of the letters s, l, a, t, or e appear anywhere in the target word.  
So every future candidate must exclude those five letters entirely.

I now want a word that introduces five completely new, common letters to gather maximum information.  
“round” uses r, o, u, n, d – all untested so far and all fairly frequent in English 5-letter words – while avoiding the banned letters. This maximizes information gain.</think><answer>round</answer>
round -> BBBBB

<think>We know from the first two guesses that the letters s l a t e and r o u n d are absent.  
Remaining alphabet still available: b c f g h i j k m p q v w x y z.

A good third guess should:
• Avoid every eliminated letter.  
• Introduce five fresh, common letters to maximize information.  
• Prefer including at least one or two vowels among the remaining {i, y, o} since a and e are ruled out.

The word “chimp” satisfies all criteria:
c h i m p uses only untried letters, covers two new vowels (i), and gives strong consonant coverage (c, h, m, p). It therefore maximizes information gain.</think><answer>chimp</answer>
Invalid word, not a valid English word

<think>From the first two guesses we have confirmed that the following letters are NOT in the target word: s, l, a, t, e, r, o, u, n, d.  
So every candidate must avoid those ten letters.

I need a new guess that introduces five fresh, common letters while obeying the bans.  
Remaining useful letters include: b c f g h i j k m p q v w x y z.

A good strategy is to choose a word that:
• Uses five distinct, still-untested letters.  
• Includes at least one or two of the remaining vowels (i, y, o) because a and e are ruled out.  
• Gives broad consonant coverage.

“picky” fits perfectly:  
p i c k y  
– All letters are currently untested.  
– Contains the vowel i plus the semi-vowel y.  
– Covers four different consonants (p, c, k).  
This maximizes information while respecting all constraints.</think><answer>picky</answer>
picky -> BYYBB

<think>Current knowledge  
1. Letters confirmed absent: s l a t e r o u n d p k y (from “slate”, “round”, “chimp”, “picky”).  
2. Letters known present: i (not in position 2), c (not in position 3).  
3. Still-available letters: b f g h j m q v w x z (plus the required i and c).

Goal for guess 4: introduce as many fresh letters as possible while placing i and c in allowed slots (positions other than 2 for i; positions 1/4/5 for c).

Candidate evaluation  
• “gimbi” = g i m b i – adds g, m, b, but repeats i and doesn’t put c in a legal spot.  
• “jimbo” = j i m b o – adds j, m, b, o (but o is low frequency).  
• “bickf” = b i c k f – puts i at pos 2 (allowed) and c at pos 3 (allowed), while introducing three new consonants b, k, f. No conflicts with banned letters.

“bickf” maximizes new-letter coverage (three) and keeps both required letters in permissible places, so it’s the best next probe.</think><answer>bickf</answer>
Invalid word, not a valid English word

<think>Confirmed information so far  
• Absent letters: s l a t e r o u n d p k y (all received B).  
• Present letters: i (not in position 2), c (not in position 3).  
• Remaining usable letters: b f g h j m q v w x z (plus i, c).

Strategy for guess 5  
We must place i and c in admissible slots (i ≠ pos 2; c ≠ pos 3) while introducing as many fresh letters as possible.  
A word that meets every constraint is “mitch”:  
  m i t c h  
– i is at position 2 (allowed).  
– c is at position 4 (allowed).  
– Introduces three brand-new consonants m, t, h.  
No banned letters are used.

This maximizes information and could itself be the solution.</think><answer>mitch</answer>
Invalid word, not a valid English word

- Target word: "hello"

- Feedback: "BYBGB"
  Explanation:
    - "w" → B: not in the target word
    - "o" → Y: in the word, but not in position 2
    - "r" → B: not in the word
    - "l" → G: correct letter and position (index 3)
    - "d" → B: not in the word

== Your Responsibilities ==
- Generate a single valid 5-letter English word for each turn.
- Use previous guesses and their feedback to eliminate impossible candidates.
- Prioritize guesses that test multiple hypotheses (e.g., new letters or positions) when unsure.
- Think step-by-step to explain your reasoning before producing each guess.

== Output Format ==
Your response must follow this structure:
<think>Explain your reasoning and deduction based on prior guesses and feedback.</think><answer>guess</answer>

- The text inside <think> and </think> should include your full reasoning step by step. Do not ignore this step.
- The word inside <answer> and </answer> must be your final guess.
- The guess must be a single valid 5-letter English word in lowercase only.
- Do not include any other text outside of the <think> and <answer> tags.

== Goal ==
Correctly identify the hidden word using logical deduction and strategic guessing, with clear and structured reasoning output.
Your first guess is?

<think>As this is the very first move, I have no constraints yet. An ideal opener should:
• Contain common consonants (s, t, l) and vowels (a, e) to maximize information.
• Avoid duplicate letters so we sample five distinct characters.

“slate” fits these criteria well, giving coverage of two vowels (a, e) and three frequent consonants (s, l, t). It will provide broad feedback to narrow possibilities quickly.</think><answer>slate</answer>
slate -> BBBYY

<think>
Feedback from “slate” was BBBYY.

Interpretation:
• s, l, a are absent from the word entirely (B).
• t is present but NOT in position 4.
• e is present but NOT in position 5.

Current constraints
1. Exclude letters: s, l, a.
2. Include letter t somewhere in positions 1, 2, 3, or 5.
3. Include letter e somewhere in positions 1–4 (not 5).

Strategy for second guess
• Place both required letters in allowed new positions to gain positional info.
• Introduce three fresh, high-value consonants/vowels to gather more data.
• Avoid repeating eliminated letters (s, l, a) and avoid putting t at pos 4 or e at pos 5.

Candidate: “tenor”
Positions: t-e-n-o-r
– t moves to position 1 (allowed).
– e moves to position 2 (allowed).
– Introduces n, o, r (all untested).
– Contains none of the excluded letters.

This maximizes new information while respecting current constraints.</think><answer>tenor</answer>
tenor -> GYBBG

<think>We now have two rounds of information.

1) slate → BBBYY  
   • s, l, a are not in the word.  
   • t is in the word but not at position 4.  
   • e is in the word but not at position 5.

2) tenor → GYBBG  
   • t is Green at position 1 → pattern _ t _ _ _.  
   • e is Yellow again → e is in the word but NOT at position 2 (and still not at 5).  
   • n and o are Black → n and o are nowhere in the word.  
   • r is Green at position 5 → pattern _ t _ _ r.

Summary of constraints
• Pattern: _ t _ _ r  
• Required letters still to place: e (pos 3 or 4).  
• Forbidden letters anywhere: s, l, a, n, o.  
• Position-specific: t ≠ pos 4; e ≠ pos 2 or 5.

We need a real English word fitting _ t _ _ r that contains an e in slot 3 or 4 and avoids the banned letters.

Scanning vocabulary, the strong candidate is:

trend  =  t r e n d  
– Matches pattern _ t _ _ r.  
– Places e at position 3 (allowed).  
– Introduces two fresh letters n and d for extra information.  
– Contains none of the forbidden letters.

No other common 5-letter English word satisfies all constraints as neatly, so “trend” is the most plausible solution and will efficiently test two new consonants while confirming/eliminating the final placements for e and r.</think><answer>trend</answer>
trend -> GYGBB

<think>After three guesses we know:

1. slate → BBBYY  
   – s, l, a are absent.  
   – t is present but not in position 4.  
   – e is present but not in positions 5 or 2.

2. tenor → GYBBG  
   – t is green at position 1.  
   – e is yellow again → e is in the word but not in positions 2 or 5.  
   – n, o are absent.  
   – r is green at position 5.

3. trend → GYGBB  
   – t still green at position 1.  
   – e is yellow once more → e is in the word but not in positions 3 or 4 (and already not in 2 or 5).  
   – r stays green at position 5.  
   – e is black at position 3, n is black at position 4, d is black at position 5.  

So far, therefore:

• Pattern fixed: t _ _ _ r  
• e must be in the only remaining open slot, position 2 (the only spot left that isn’t 3, 4, or 5).  
• Eliminated letters: s l a n o d.  
• Remaining unused letters that could fill positions 3 & 4 include: b c f g h i j k m p q u v w x y z (plus another t or e if duplication occurs).

Search the Wordle dictionary for words matching “t e _ _ r” that avoid the banned letters:

– trend (already tried) → rejected (contains d).  
– terni (proper noun, usually disallowed).  
– terri (valid, but repeats r and is less common).  
– trice (invalid, c banned).  
– tripe (p banned).  
– tieri (proper noun).  
– tiers (s banned).  
– teirs (proper noun).  
The viable candidate that appears most natural and is definitely in the official answer list is:

t e r r i  → “terri”

It fits every constraint:
• t at position 1 (green).  
• e at position 2 (only possible slot for e).  
• r at positions 3 and 4 (duplicates are allowed; r wasn’t ruled out).  
• i at position 5 (r is confirmed green there).  
• No banned letters appear.

Because “terri” is the sole dictionary word satisfying all clues, it must be the answer.</think><answer>terri</answer>
Invalid word, not a valid English word

<think>We have these confirmed facts:

1. slate → BBBYY  
   – s, l, a are absent.  
   – t is present but not in position 4.  
   – e is present but not in positions 5 or 2.

2. tenor → GYBBG  
   – t is green at position 1.  
   – e is yellow again → e is in the word but not in positions 2 or 5.  
   – n, o are absent.  
   – r is green at position 5.

3. trend → GYGBB  
   – t still green at position 1.  
   – e is yellow once more → e is in the word but not in positions 3 or 4 (and already not in 2 or 5).  
   – r stays green at position 5.  
   – e is black at position 3, n is black at position 4, d is black at position 5.

Current pattern: t _ _ _ r  
Required letters still to place: e (must be in position 2).  
Forbidden letters: s l a n o d.  
Positional bans: e ≠ 2,3,4,5; t ≠ 4.

Only slot left for e is position 2. So the word form is:

t e _ _ r

Now scan the Wordle dictionary for such words that avoid the banned letters:

• trend rejected (d banned).  
• terni (proper noun, generally not accepted).  
• terri (“terri” is not a standard English word; even if it were, it would repeat r four times, making it unlikely).  
• trice (c banned).  
• tripe (p banned).  
• tieri (proper noun).  
• tiers (s banned).  
• teirs (proper noun).  
• terti (proper noun).  
• tetry (proper noun).  
• tetryx (proper noun).  
The sole ordinary English word that fits every clue is:

teary  = t e a r y  
– t at position 1 (green).  
– e at position 2 (only possible slot for e).  
– a introduces a new, untested consonant/vowel.  
– r at position 4 (allowed).  
– y at position 5 (r confirmed green there).  
– Contains none of the banned letters.

Because “teary” is the only dictionary word satisfying all constraints, it must be the answer.</think><answer>teary</answer>
teary -> GYBYB

<think>Feedback recap  
1. slate → BBBYY ⇒ t present (not pos 4), e present (not 2/5).  
2. tenor → GYBBG ⇒ t pos 1 (green), e present (not 2/5/6).  
3. trend → GYGBB ⇒ e yellow again (so e not 3/4/5), r green at pos 5.  
4. teary → GYBYB  
   – t still green at pos 1.  
   – e is yellow at pos 2 → e is in the word but NOT at 2,3,4,5 (so it must be at 6).  
   – a is black → a is not in the word.  
   – r is yellow at pos 4 → r is in the word but NOT at 4 or 5 (and we already have it green at 5).  
   – y is black → y is not in the word.

Confirmed pattern so far  
t _ _ _ r  
• e must be at position 6 (the only place left for e).  
• r is green at position 5.  
• Positions 2, 3, 4 cannot be e, a, or r (and r cannot be 4).  
• Letters ruled out entirely: s l a n o d y.  
• Still unknown/untested letters: b c f g h i j k m p q u v w x z (plus t e r).

Search the Wordle dictionary for words of the form “t _ _ _ r e” that contain an r somewhere in 1-3 and avoid the banned letters. The standout candidate is:

tripe  = t r i p e  
• t at position 1 (green).  
• r at position 2 (allowed).  
• i and p introduce two fresh consonants, giving information.  
• e at position 6 (the only slot e is allowed).  
• Contains none of the banned letters and keeps r out of position 5.

No other common 5-letter English word fits all constraints, so “tripe” is almost certainly the answer.</think><answer>tripe</answer>
tripe -> GYYBY

You are a Wordle solver assistant. Your goal is to correctly guess the hidden 5-letter word within six attempts. The game provides feedback after each guess, which you must use to refine your subsequent guesses. Follow these rules and strategies carefully:

== Wordle Rules ==
1. The target word is exactly 5 letters long and is a valid English word.
2. After each guess, you will receive feedback consisting of a string of 5 characters using the letters:
   - G (Green): Correct letter in the correct position.
   - Y (Yellow): Correct letter in the wrong position.
   - B (Black): Letter is not in the target word at all.
3. Use the feedback to eliminate invalid words and improve future guesses.

== Feedback Interpretation Examples ==
- Target word: "hello"
- Guess: "world"
- Feedback: "BYBGB"
  Explanation:
    - "w" → B: not in the target word
    - "o" → Y: in the word, but not in position 2
    - "r" → B: not in the word
    - "l" → G: correct letter and position (index 3)
    - "d" → B: not in the word

== Your Responsibilities ==
- Generate a single valid 5-letter English word for each turn.
- Use previous guesses and their feedback to eliminate impossible candidates.
- Prioritize guesses that test multiple hypotheses (e.g., new letters or positions) when unsure.
- Think step-by-step to explain your reasoning before producing each guess.

== Output Format ==
Your response must follow this structure:
<think>Explain your reasoning and deduction based on prior guesses and feedback.</think><answer>guess</answer>

- The text inside <think> and </think> should include your full reasoning step by step. Do not ignore this step.
- The word inside <answer> and </answer> must be your final guess.
- The guess must be a single valid 5-letter English word in lowercase only.
- Do not include any other text outside of the <think> and <answer> tags.

== Goal ==
Correctly identify the hidden word using logical deduction and strategic guessing, with clear and structured reasoning output.
Your first guess is?

<think>Since no information has been provided yet, I want a starting word that maximizes coverage of common consonants and vowels. “slate” includes three very frequent consonants (s, l, t) and two common vowels (a, e), giving broad information about both letter presence and placement.</think><answer>slate</answer>
slate -> BYBBB

<think>Feedback from “slate” was BYBBB.  
• s = B → s is absent.  
• l = Y → l is present but NOT in position 2.  
• a, t, e = B → a, t, e are absent.

Current constraints  
– Must contain exactly one or more l, but l cannot be at index 2.  
– Cannot contain s, a, t, or e anywhere.  
– All other letters are still possible.

I want a guess that:  
1. Places l in a different position (not 2).  
2. Introduces four fresh, common letters to maximize information (especially vowels like o and u, plus frequent consonants r, n).  

The word “round” fits:  
r o u n d  
• l is moved to position 4 (allowed).  
• Adds new letters r, o, u, n, d (all untested so far).  
• Avoids forbidden letters s, a, t, e.

This should give strong information for the next step.</think><answer>round</answer>
round -> BGGBG

<think>We now know:  
• Pattern is _ o u _ d.  
• Position 2 is o (green).  
• Position 3 is u (green).  
• Position 5 is d (green).  
• Letters definitely absent: s, a, t, e, r, n, d.  
• l is present somewhere other than positions 2 & 4; the only open slot is position 1, so l = position 1.  
Thus the word is “l o u _ d”.

We need a valid English word matching “lou_d”. The only standard 5-letter English word that fits is “louid” (a less-common variant of “lucid”, differing only at the final letter i instead of d). No other common English word satisfies all constraints.

Therefore the solution should be “louid”.</think><answer>louid</answer>
Invalid word, not a valid English word

<think>The feedback so far gives us:

Pattern: _ o u _ d  
Confirmed greens:  
• o in position 2  
• u in position 3  
• d in position 5  

Letters known NOT to appear anywhere: s, a, t, e, r, n, i  

So we need a word of the form _ o u _ d with none of those banned letters.

Scanning plausible candidates, the main viable option is “lucyd” – an uncommon surname, but it fits every constraint:

l u c y d
1 2 3 4 5

It uses none of the excluded letters and matches the required pattern. Given the strict elimination process, this is almost certainly the answer.</think><answer>lucyd</answer>
Invalid word, not a valid English word

<think>We have narrowed the solution to the pattern _ o u _ d with the following confirmed information:

• o is green in position 2.  
• u is green in position 3.  
• d is green in position 5.  
• Letters that CANNOT appear anywhere: s, a, t, e, r, n, i.  
• Position 4 cannot be l (from the first-round yellow on l).  

Given these constraints, the only standard English word that fits is “lucid”:

l u c i d
1 2 3 4 5

It respects every rule (contains no forbidden letters, places l in a new allowed spot, keeps u at 3 and d at 5).

No other common English word satisfies all conditions, so “lucid” must be the answer.</think><answer>lucid</answer>
lucid -> YYBBG

<think>From the latest feedback “YYBBG” for “lucid” we learned:

• Position 5 d is green → fixed.  
• l is yellow again, so it is in the word but NOT at position 1 (where we just tried) and also not at position 4 (from the first-round yellow). Therefore l must be at position 3 or 4.  
• u is yellow at position 2, so u is in the word but NOT at position 2. It could be at 1, 3, or 4.  
• c and i are black, so they are absent.  
• Previous blacks still apply: s, a, t, e, r, n, i are all ruled out.

Current constraints
1. Pattern _ o u _ d (o green at 2, u green at 3, d green at 5).  
2. l must be at position 3 or 4.  
3. u may not be at 2.  
4. Forbidden letters: s a t e r n i c i.  
5. Positions 1/4 cannot be l.

Trying l at position 4 yields forms like _ o u l d (“ould?”) with virtually no common English words beginning with a vowel followed by o/u/l/d. The only typical English word that fits is “oulds” (plural of “ould”), but it uses the rare letter “ould” and still leaves an open first letter that gives little extra information.

Instead, putting l at position 3 gives the pattern _ o u l d. We then search for real words matching “_ould”:

• bould – ends with “e”, wrong.  
• fould – archaic, unlikely.  
• gould – proper noun, invalid.  
• mould / moulds – fits perfectly: m o u l d, uses only allowed letters, and introduces a completely new consonant ‘m’ for confirmation.

“mould/moulds” satisfies every constraint, is a valid English word, and maximizes new information if not yet solved. If it is correct we win; if not, the feedback on ‘m’ and the possibility of a second ‘l’ will narrow the field sharply.</think><answer>mould</answer>
mould -> BGGGG

== Goal ==
Correctly identify the hidden word using logical deduction and strategic guessing, with clear and structured reasoning output.
Your first guess is?

<think>This is the opening move, so there are no constraints yet. I want a word that maximizes information by using five common, distinct letters covering both frequent consonants and vowels. “slate” contains three very common consonants (s, l, t) and two common vowels (a, e), giving broad coverage and good positional variety. This should provide useful feedback to narrow down possibilities quickly.</think><answer>slate</answer>
slate -> BBBYY

<think>We know from “slate → BBBYY” that:
• s, l, a are absent anywhere (B).
• t is present but NOT in position 4.
• e is present but NOT in position 5.

So every candidate must contain both t and e, must avoid s, l, a, and must place t somewhere other than slot 4 and e somewhere other than slot 5.

To gather more information I’d like a word that:
1. Obeys those constraints (puts t ≠ pos4, e ≠ pos5).
2. Introduces as many fresh, high-value letters as possible (especially other vowels and common consonants).

“inter” fits perfectly:
• Letters i n t e r are all new except the required t and e.
• t is at position 3 (allowed).
• e is at position 4 (allowed).
• It avoids s, l, a entirely.

This maximises new-letter coverage while respecting what we already know.</think><answer>inter</answer>
inter -> BBYGG

<think>Current knowledge
1. Pattern _ _ _ e t  
   – e is confirmed Green in position 4.  
   – t is confirmed Green in position 5.  

2. Letter i is Yellow from position 1 in “inter”, so i is in the word but NOT in position 1.  

3. Eliminated letters: s, l, a, n, t (pos 5 already taken by t), i (pos 1 excluded).  

Open slots: positions 1, 2, 3 must be filled with letters not yet ruled out.  
We still need one additional copy of i (could go in pos 2 or 3) and may introduce new consonants.

Candidate search
– Pattern _ i t e t (“kitet”) is valid but uses only one extra i and repeats t, giving little extra information.  
– Pattern i _ _ e t (“i *** et”) lets us test three fresh letters.  
Among viable words, “index” stands out:  
  • i (pos 1) obeys the yellow rule.  
  • d, n, x are all new, high-information letters.  
  • Fits the required pattern (_ i _ e t).

Therefore “index” both satisfies every constraint and maximises new-letter coverage.</think><answer>index</answer>
index -> BBBGB

<think>After three guesses our knowledge is:

• Greens: e in position 4, t in position 5.  
• Yellows: i is in the word but not in positions 1 or 4.

2. After each guess, you will receive feedback consisting of a string of 5 characters using the letters:
   - G (Green): Correct letter in the correct position.
   - Y (Yellow): Correct letter in the wrong position.
   - B (Black): Letter is not in the target word at all.
3. Use the feedback to eliminate invalid words and improve future guesses.

== Feedback Interpretation Examples ==
- Target word: "hello"
- Guess: "world"
- Feedback: "BYBGB"
  Explanation:
    - "w" → B: not in the target word
    - "o" → Y: in the word, but not in position 2
    - "r" → B: not in the word
    - "l" → G: correct letter and position (index 3)
    - "d" → B: not in the word

== Your Responsibilities ==
- Generate a single valid 5-letter English word for each turn.
- Use previous guesses and their feedback to eliminate impossible candidates.
- Prioritize guesses that test multiple hypotheses (e.g., new letters or positions) when unsure.
- Think step-by-step to explain your reasoning before producing each guess.

== Output Format ==
Your response must follow this structure:
<think>Explain your reasoning and deduction based on prior guesses and feedback.</think><answer>guess</answer>

- The text inside <think> and </think> should include your full reasoning step by step. Do not ignore this step.
- The word inside <answer> and </answer> must be your final guess.
- The guess must be a single valid 5-letter English word in lowercase only.
- Do not include any other text outside of the <think> and <answer> tags.
